parts.instructions: You are going to read reviews of five books that describe walking in the Rocky Mountain District. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: Mountain Walks
passage.content:
A) Exploring the Rocky District
This is a well-organized book, ideal for a two to five walks with information about every walk including distance, expected time for completion, and difficulty level. The author has an easy, straightforward writing style and the excellent detailed maps. The photographs are designed not just to show the landscape but to help the walker to find the right path. The book is aimed at the experienced walker who wants a detailed and comprehensive guide, but because of its organization there is something here for the casual walker too. The route descriptions are good and the background information is especially detailed.

B) More Rocky District Walks
This book is suitable with detailed maps and good walking descriptions. It is different from guidebook A as it offers walks for the less experienced. Some walks are designed for taking small children happily with you. All walks can be completed comfortably in under three hours. The author clearly enjoys the area very much and suggests the best places to stop for picnics and somewhere to visit if the weather is not especially favorable. For hikers, it's perfect. The one criticism is the book, as the photographs focus only on the landscape and not the paths, it can be difficult to find your way.

C) A Walking Tour of the Rocky District
The wealth of information in this book about the mountains and local areas will really help you make the most of your visit. Designed for the individual traveler, this book is a single walk, made up a week. It is designed that this book will help you to understand the landscape and be amazed at all that you can find all the amazing things to see. The number of colour photographs, providing good, detailed route descriptions and it has an excellent selection of colour photographs. This look at mountain photography is essential to get your bearings again.

This useful little pocket-sized book, although not for the serious climber, is treasure to look at. There is a good appendix that includes a mountain in the area for every walk. The detail describes from the top in the comfort of your armchair. At least your enjoyment of the view is not affected by the weather! There are 20 walks, either by motor vehicle or high-speed mountain, providing good detailed route descriptions and some sample details as you progress through the terrain. You can have fun trying to get there by public transport: travel information for the most direct transport to the starting point is included.

passage.title: The Book Department
passage.content:
There was a small breeze when Christina came out for her lunch as she usually did, even when it was raining, instead of going up to the store canteen. You could never get a table to yourself there, and whenever she sat with you always wanted to complain about the shop, the customers, the management or the canteen food. Everyone at Goldwyn's seemed to have a complaint of some kind.

[7]

Christina herself had been in the book department for more than four years. She had started as a junior, teaching everyone prices and breaking the till once a week in her efforts to serve customers quickly. Now she was Head Salesperson and moved calmly around the department between the bright new paperbacks, knowing that book customers liked to take their time, unlike the people who shopped through other parts of the shop with never an increase to spare.

[8]

She was told this was Mr Parker's right-hand person – and heaven knows he needed one – and was sometimes asked into his office to meet a favoured publisher's representative.

[9]

The book department, partly due to Mr Parker's weak administration and partly because it was thought to be sophisticated, was the only department in Goldwyn's where you did not have to wear black. This led to some confusion as to who was an assistant and who was a customer, not everyone was used to uniformed and accounted for the elderly ladies and lack of people who picked up a book they wanted but were afraid of having their elbows grabbed by the same defective before they could find someone to take their money.

[10]

Christina was wearing her grey suit today. She liked the grey suit. She had liked it for a very long time and said of a woman's advice that it was better to buy an expensive suit that would last than to keep buying cheap suits that looked very smart but thin based in the street to look at it, but it would stand having its skirt taken up or let down according to the swings of fashion.

[11]

She always had lunch at work, at much or one can't early job that important one, from wine till five-thirty. She liked Goldwyn's, but she was always glad to get away from it at lunchtime, even though it meant queuing for a table in one of the restaurants and tea-shops that fed the local shop-workers. Here people tended to eat with their eyes on the clock, often failing to taste what they ate and thinking only of getting their food down so that they could get back to their jobs on time.

Alice, who was her junior, was always meeting people at lunchtime. Even if it was only a quick coffee in the Goodwill she was always giggling so much that there was nothing so much that life standing up and down with the rest of the world. At Goldwyn's at she was someone.
